standard_gauge.name: Sassnitz
standard_gauge.description: Sassnitz is the white harbor town by the sea, it has about 10,000 residents, with that, it is the second-largest city. She owns a port where until 2000 the "Stenaline" a ferry to Trelleborg (Sweden) was departing. From this port, freight trains were shipped to the USSR during the GDR era.

standard_gauge.name: Lancken
standard_gauge.description: Lancken is a part of Sassnitz. This station is only equipped for the essentials, such as an intercom system, a timetable, and a shelter. In addition, there is a track to the chalk mine.

standard_gauge.name: Sagard
standard_gauge.description: Sagard is a small town with 2,460 residents. Her train station looks more modern than Lancken's.

standard_gauge.name: Baltic resort Binz
standard_gauge.description: The Baltic resort Binz train station is the main train station of the popular seaside resort Binz on the island of Ruegen. It was opened on May 15, 1939. The reception building dates back to 1938 and is still in operation today. The station has three platform tracks and is accessible for people with disabilities. It is regularly served by regional and long-distance trains, offering connections to cities such as Berlin, Hamburg, and Munich. The central location of the station allows travelers to reach the town center, the pier, and the fine sandy beach within a few minutes on foot. In addition, there is a connection to public transportation and taxis at the station, making it easy to continue traveling within Binz and beyond.

standard_gauge.name: Lietzow (Ruegen)
standard_gauge.description: The Lietzow (Ruegen) train station was opened in 1891 as a stop on the Stralsund–Sassnitz railway line and is located on the southern edge of Lietzow. Since 1939, the railway line to Binz branches off here, making Lietzow an important transfer point on the island of Ruegen. In 2009/10, an extensive renovation of the station took place, during which the number of main tracks was reduced to four. Today, the station is served by regional trains of the Ostdeutsche Eisenbahn GmbH (ODEG), which offer connections between Rostock, Stralsund, Sassnitz, and Binz. However, there is always a shuttle train that goes to the other stop.

standard_gauge.name: Bergen(Ruegen)
standard_gauge.description: Bergen is the district town of Ruegen and is the most populous city on Ruegen. It is one of the central traffic hubs of the island of Ruegen. It has facilities such as bicycle parking, parking spaces, and taxis. The DB Travel Center offers personal consultation and ticket sales.

standard_gauge.name: Teschenhagen
standard_gauge.description: The Teschenhagen station is located in the municipality of Sehlen on the island of Ruegen and was opened on July 1, 1883. It is located on the Stralsund–Sassnitz railway line and has two tracks with corresponding platforms. Originally designed as a train station with freight traffic, Teschenhagen now serves as a stop for regional trains of the Ostdeutsche Eisenbahn GmbH (ODEG), which offer connections between Rostock, Stralsund, and Sassnitz or Binz. The historic reception building is still intact and was partially inhabited until mid-2022.

standard_gauge.name: Samtens
standard_gauge.description: The Samtens train station is located on the outskirts of the eponymous municipality on Ruegen. It is also located on the Stralsund–Sassnitz railway line and is served by regional trains of the ODEG. After the expansion of the Electronic Signal Box (ESTW) from Altefaehr to Bergen, the station is unstaffed. The platforms were modernized, with the main platform being renovated and a new outer platform towards Bergen being constructed.

standard_gauge.name: Rambin (Ruegen)
standard_gauge.description: The Rambin (Ruegen) station was opened on July 1, 1883, on the Stralsund–Sassnitz railway line and is located on the outskirts of the municipality of Rambin. It has two tracks with corresponding platforms and is also served by regional trains of the ODEG, which offer hourly connections between Rostock, Stralsund, and the seaside resorts of the island of Ruegen. The historic reception building is still present, but no longer in operation.

standard_gauge.name: Altefaehr
standard_gauge.description: The Altefaehr train station is located about one kilometer southeast of the center of Altefaehr on the island of Ruegen, just around 200 meters from the Strelasund. It was opened on July 1, 1883, and is located on the Stralsund–Sassnitz railway line. Before the construction of the Ruegen Causeway in the 1930s, Altefaehr was only accessible by ferry; the original station was then located closer to the ferry terminal. Today, regional express trains of the Ostdeutsche Eisenbahn GmbH (ODEG) stop here every two hours on the route from Rostock via Stralsund to Sassnitz or Binz. The central location of the station allows travelers to reach the town center and the waterfront promenade on foot in just a few minutes.

standard_gauge.name: Stralsund Ruegendamm
standard_gauge.description: The Stralsund station Ruegendamm, also known as Ruegendamm Station, was opened on October 5, 1936, and is located on the Stralsund–Sassnitz railway line. It is located a few meters before the Ziegelgraben Bridge, which connects Stralsund with the island of Ruegen. The station has a partially covered central platform and is served by regional trains of the ODEG, which offer connections between Rostock, Stralsund, and Sassnitz or Binz. Parking is available in front of the station, and there is a connection to public transportation. A ticket counter or other service facilities are not available, however.

narrow_gauge.name: Putbus
narrow_gauge.description: Putbus is a small town on the island of Ruegen with about 4,000 residents. The Putbus train station is located in the center of the town and is served by the Ruegensche Kleinbahn, a narrow-gauge railway that connects Putbus with Binz, Goehren, and Lauterbach. The station building is a listed building and was built in 1899.
